<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Le sourire: Journal sérieux, Nov. 1899  
1899  
Title block: only state  
Headpiece A Pig, a Dwarf, Flowers, and Leaves: only state  
Mimeograph in brownish-black ink, with wood-block prints in black ink on cream wove paper; 397 × 513 mm (full sheet); 397 × 256 mm (folded sheet); 24 × 94 mm (title block), 105 × 187 mm (headpiece)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Mr. and Mrs. Carter H. Harrison Collection, 1948.421  
Kornfeld 57 (title block) and 60 B (headpiece)  
For the inside and back, see fig. 109.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Gauguin produced nine issues of Le sourire (The Smile), his “serious newspaper,”as well as three supplements; this issue is the third and did not contain a supplement. Using the new technology of mimeography that he encountered while clerking as a draftsman in Papeete, he created the satirical newspaper for local monthly distribution. The machine that Gauguin used was likely an Edison Mimeograph Model 0. These devices were manufactured in Chicago by the A. B. Dick Company and had only become available in 1897. So popular was the machine, which greatly improved the efficiency of bureaucratic offices, that by the time Gauguin gained access to one in 1899, he described it as “all the rage.” It is likely that this duplicating technology also appealed to the artist on a conceptual level, considering his history of experimentation with various transfer processes.

The format of Le sourire is not immediately intuitive. The unusual orientation of text relative to the folding of the sheets indicates that the journal was intended to be read by turning the pages from left to right. Gauguin hoped to use the mimeograph machine to print images and text simultaneously (see Technical Overview). Unfortunately, the technology had limits that thwarted his aesthetic ambitions; the vignettes sprinkled throughout the text of the August, September, and October 1899 issues were rendered partially illegible due to the broken lines and uneven printing. In this and later issues of the journal, he integrated wood-block prints, such as the headpiece, to improve the clarity of his illustrations. In another copy of the November 1899 issue of Le sourire in the Art Institute’s collection, Three People, a Mask, a Fox, and a Bird (cat. 111) was used as the headpiece.

An impression of Pig, a Dwarf, Flowers, and Leaves (Kornfeld 60 B) adorns the front page of this issue. The irregularity of the impression appears to be a result of selective adhesion of the ink to the block. An excess of linseed oil is indicated by the reticulated pattern of ink deposition and the strike-through of oil on the verso of the sheet as well as onto the sheet facing it.

The title block appears twice in this issue, once on the first page within the larger image and again on the last page. On the recto the title block was printed in a thick layer of black ink that contained a significant amount of linseed oil. This is evidenced by some oil strike-through on the verso.

The text of this issue was printed in brownish-black ink applied through a mimeograph stencil. The stencil itself was responsible for the grainy appearance of the text (see Technical Overview).

The paper that Gauguin selected is only slightly higher quality than newsprint. It is a thin, soft, short-fibered paper with a slight texture that is visible in transmitted light. Because the paper was formatted for use with the mimeograph machine and because Gauguin was notoriously low on money and supplies, it is possible that he procured this paper from the office where he worked and where he returned to do his mimeograph printing. This same paper appears again in Gauguin’s later work, including the transfer drawings Woman with a Cat (cat. 123) and Sister of Charity (cat. 125).

397 × 513 mm (full sheet); 397 × 256 mm (folded sheet); 24 × 94 mm (title block), 105 × 187 mm (headpiece)

The issue is in fair condition. There are edge tears and small losses in the sheet.  
Mary Broadway and Harriet K. Stratis

The nature of the media and their application, as well as the condition of the artwork, were assessed through visual examination using normal, transmitted, and raking light; microscope magnification (80–300×); and ultraviolet-light examination (254 and 365 nm).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Gauguin gave his publication the subtitle Journal sérieux for the first four months of its production, but by December of 1899, he changed it to Journal méchant (“wicked newspaper”).

Paul Gauguin, “Le sourire” de Paul Gauguin, with an introduction by L. G. Bouge, facsimile ed. (G.-P. Maisonneuve, 1952).

For Gauguin’s work in Papeete, see Bengt Danielsson, Gauguin in the South Seas, trans. Reginald Spink (Doubleday, 1964).

“J’ai créé en outre un journal ‘Le Sourire’ autographié Système Edison, qui fait fureur” (I have also created a newspaper, The Smile, using the Edison printing system, which is all the rage). Gauguin to Monfreid, Dec. 1899, in Lettres de Gauguin à Daniel de Monfreid, ed. Annie Joly-Segalen, introduction by Victor Segalen (G. Falaize, 1950), p. 151, no. 59. Translation by the authors.

For more on Gauguin’s experiments with transfer techniques, see Peter Kort Zegers, “In the Kitchen with Paul Gauguin: Devising Recipes for a Symbolist Graphic Aesthetic,” in The Broad Spectrum: Studies in Materials, Techniques, and Conservation of Color on Paper, ed. Harriet K. Stratis and Britt Salvesen (Archetype, 2002), pp. 138–44. See also Richard S. Field, Paul Gauguin: Monotypes, exh. cat. (Philadelphia Museum of Art, 1973).

Receipt from Maurice Gobin, June 25, 1948, six pages from “Le Sourire,” sold to Mr. Carter H. Harrison, curatorial object file, Department of Prints and Drawings, Art Institute of Chicago.
